Observation: They had to factor money they lost in relation to the donation.
Insight: attractiveness of using a chance mechanism that wears out fast, and becomes really suspicious.
Summary: Participants tend to focus on minimising the loss rather than gaining a profit.

Observation: Took longer because they gave it a few try and looked at how their basket went up or down.
Chance mechanics are relatively high in cognitive load
There can be an element of pressure if there was a time limit.
Participants focus on minimising the loss rather than gaining a profit after awhile.
Participants doubt information when interfaces seem to honest.
Insight: lack of control which deters people from donating, even if its an amount they might usually donate.
Summary: Participants don't donate if there is not enough information about where the donation is going.

Observation: Participants felt like they didn't have control in the amount of money they donated.
The choice was simple, didn't take long to think.
If there isn't enough information about where the donation is going to, they won't donate.
Using languages like "do not donate" makes them feel bad to not do so.
Everyone seems suspicious.
Insight: suspicion when donation amounts become high because people didn't know where the money went to.
EffectiveIn: Large donations that give people a sense of achievement.
Summary: People tried to outsmart the mechanism, leading to a sense of competitive spirit.

Observation: Seems to be a fresh/new mechanism.
Some of them tried to outsmart the mechanism.
Insight: anxiety when users made a huge donation commitment.

Observation: People tried to keep winning the prize.
People felt a sense of "competitive spirit".
Almost everyone talked about the gift, no one noticed how expensive the donation was. (35 instead of 5)
EffectiveIn: Donations that brings users closer to the organisation.
Summary: Gift bundle rewards people for making a donation, making it a good effort.

Observation: Gift bundle only appealed to some people.
Being rewarded with a gift makes it feel like the organisation is putting some effort behind the donation.
Friends make donation more comfortable.
Insight: influence when friends who are closer to users made them donate personally.
Scenarios: Split cost of Rice with Participants
Actionable: Leverage on the community to build confidence
EffectiveIn: Donations that brings users closer to the organisation.
Summary: Friends make donations less intimidating by sharing their support.

Observation: People felt like they were ‘real’ supporters.
Scenarios: Split cost of Rice with Participants

Observation: Makes the donation seem more affordable because it's shared across many people.
Scenarios: Split cost of Rice with Participants

Observation: Confusing mechanism that couldn’t ensure them of the amount they were donating
Insight: community even though people found it unlikely that everyone will do "good".
Actionable: Leverage on the community to build confidence
EffectiveIn: Large donations that give people a sense of achievement.
Summary: People wanted a clear understanding of the total amount of funds raised.

Observation: People wanted a clear understanding of what the total amount of funds raised is currently.
People mentioned that there was a relationship with the organisation/shop.
Summary: People felt the shop should do more than them.

Observation: They also felt like it was uncommon to have so much decision making power.
Someone felt like he should be doing more, because the shop was already doing so much.
Insight: pressure when someone else is putting more effort than you (in donating).
Actionable: Leverage on the community to build confidence
EffectiveIn: Donations that brings users closer to the organisation.

Observation: They felt happy that the shop is donating as well.
Insight: positive impression when someone explains why users donated.

Observation: Some people doubt the shop would donate that much.
They felt bad if they went lower than the default point.
Insight: comfort when the default are just around people's donation appetite.
Summary: People felt bad when they didn't conform to the default "minimum".

Observation: They think the shop owner doesn’t need donations.
The feedback from friend makes it very engaging.
Insight: influence when users knew someone donated before them.
Actionable: Leverage on the community to build confidence
EffectiveIn: Donations that brings users closer to the organisation.
Summary: People are afraid of ruining the donation "streak".

Observation: It felt like they were helping and earning at the same time.
Insight: responsibility to continue a chain of "donations".

Observation: Users reported a high cognitive load.
Users think about the shop’s participation in it.
Some people are afraid of ruining the "streak" of donation.
Some people didn't know that the $2 discount only applies when they donate more than $15.
People felt like there’s a minimum requirement to help.
Insight: a sense of inferiority and a tendency to avoid options that too “easy”.
Actionable: Build trust within users and organisation
EffectiveIn: Donations that brings users closer to the organisation.
Summary: People compare tiers to decide which one is more suitable for them.

Observation: People are afraid of other people viewing their decisions.
Insight: a sense of additional effort and significance, when a gift is added to a donation.

Observation: The gift makes it feel like there’s an effort to drive donations.
Insight: relationship between the donor and the organization they are supporting.

Observation: People started to compare different tiers, and took notice of which one was more suitable for them.
People started to look at how the average might be fake.
Insight: influence to what users think are their “acceptable” donation by making the default just a little higher.
Summary: Peer pressure influenced people to focus on the community.

Observation: Pressure to start the community “drive”.
100% of people commented about the community aspect instead of the default.
Peer pressure, didn’t want to look bad to others.
People reported a lack of control over the donation amount and interface.
Insight: unfamiliarity, when this interface became too complex because people have no way to predict what might happen to their money.

Observation: This feel like a "gimmick" and didn't feel real enough.
